problems.name: Dishes remain dirty
problems.description: Food soil is still visible after the wash cycle finishes.

actions.title: Raise the main wash temperature
actions.summary: Ensure the machine reaches a hot enough wash phase to break down grease and detergent.
instructions: Set the temperature or program to reach at least 60°C before the next cycle.
Select an Intensive or Hygiene program instead of Eco when heavy soil is present.
When cookware allows, choose a 65°C cycle to clear stubborn residue.

actions.title: Pick a longer, high-heat cycle
actions.summary: Quick or Eco programs may not provide enough time or heat for baked-on soil.
instructions: Switch to an Intensive, Hygiene, or Heavy cycle for cookware with dried food.
If Intensive is unavailable, run a Normal program with an extra rinse option.
Avoid Quick cycles until the dishwasher is consistently cleaning well again.

causes.name: Under-dosing of detergent or device product

actions.title: Increase the detergent dosage
actions.summary: Too little detergent leaves grease and starch behind.
instructions: Increase the detergent setting or add one extra push on the dispenser/device.
Use the Boost Clean or heavy soil mode for the next two cycles.
Re-check dosage once the load finishes to avoid product build-up.

actions.title: Clean the filter system
actions.summary: Blocked filters restrict water circulation and allow soil to recirculate.
instructions: Remove the filter assembly and rinse it thoroughly under warm water.
Soak the filter in hot water for 10 minutes if grease has built up.
Reinstall the filter securely to prevent bypass leaks.

actions.title: Clear spray-arm jets
actions.summary: Spray arms clogged with debris cannot deliver proper pressure.
instructions: Detach upper and lower spray arms and flush them under running water.
Use a toothpick or soft brush to clear any blocked nozzles.
Spin each arm by hand before reinstalling to confirm free rotation.

actions.title: Improve rack loading
actions.summary: Items that touch or block spray arms prevent full coverage.
instructions: Space dishes roughly 2 cm apart so water can hit every surface.
Avoid tall trays or pans that block the spray arm path.
Raise the upper rack if adjustable to create clearance for large plates.

causes.name: Heater element or temperature sensor malfunction

actions.title: Run heater diagnostics
actions.summary: If the unit cannot heat, professional service may be required.
instructions: Run the built-in self-test or diagnostic mode if your dishwasher supports it.
Listen for heating during a hot cycle; if water stays cold, contact support.
Schedule an authorized technician to inspect the heater and temperature sensor.

problems.name: Spots or film on glassware
problems.description: Water spots or streaks remain on glass and dishes after drying.

actions.title: Raise the rinse-aid dosage
actions.summary: Rinse aid helps water sheet off glass instead of leaving spots.
instructions: Adjust the rinse-aid dial to level 3 or higher.
If spotting persists, move to level 4 for the next few cycles.
Wipe the dispenser nozzle clean to maintain even flow.

actions.title: Enable hard-water features
actions.summary: Mineral-heavy water needs additional softening to avoid spotting.
instructions: Refill dishwasher salt and confirm the cap seals firmly.
Match the built-in softener setting to your local water hardness.
Turn on the hard-water or mineral-guard mode if available.

causes.name: Rinse aid dispenser empty or malfunctioning

actions.title: Restore rinse-aid flow
actions.summary: A clogged or empty dispenser cannot dose properly.
instructions: Top up the rinse-aid reservoir until the indicator shows full.
Clean the dispenser nozzle and flap to remove dried product.
Run a normal cycle and verify the indicator drops afterward.

causes.name: Salt reservoir empty or valve blocked

actions.title: Service the salt regeneration system
actions.summary: Without salt the softener cannot protect against lime scale.
instructions: Refill the salt reservoir with dishwasher salt until brine covers the opening.
Check the valve area for salt bridges and break them up with a spoon handle.
Rinse away spills to prevent corrosion around the cap.

causes.name: Improper drying or door opened too early

actions.title: Improve the drying phase
actions.summary: Opening the door early leaves condensed droplets on glass.
instructions: Keep the door closed until the full drying cycle completes.
Use an AutoDry or ExtraDry option for glassware loads.
Let items sit for 10 minutes after the end signal before unloading.

problems.name: Powdery or gritty residue
problems.description: Detergent grains or food residue settle on dishes after washing.

causes.name: Overloading the racks, blocking water flow

actions.title: Space items for full spray coverage
actions.summary: Crowded racks trap detergent and food particles.
instructions: Leave about 2 cm between plates and bowls.
Angle cups and bowls so water drains freely.
Avoid stacking utensils; use the cutlery rack or basket separators.

causes.name: Powder detergent not fully dissolved in cold cycle

actions.title: Help detergent dissolve
actions.summary: Low-temperature cycles can leave powder trapped in the dispenser.
instructions: Run Normal or Intensive cycles when using powder detergent.
If residue continues, switch to a liquid or gel formula.
Enable pre-rinse only when dishes are heavily soiled.

actions.title: Use the correct detergent amount
actions.summary: Too much detergent leaves a chalky film as the water dries.
instructions: Measure detergent according to water hardness and soil level.
Dial the automatic dispenser down one step once loads are clean.
Perform one cycle with standard dosage to confirm improvement.

actions.title: Raise temperature for residue removal
actions.summary: Hotter water keeps fats dissolved until the final rinse.
instructions: Set the cycle temperature to at least 55°C for the next few washes.
Enable the anti-residue or hygiene option if your model provides it.
Confirm the hot-water supply entering the dishwasher is at least 49°C.

causes.name: Blocked filter or partially clogged spray arms

actions.title: Deep clean the wash system
actions.summary: Clogs recirculate food particles and undissolved detergent.
instructions: Clean the filter thoroughly under running water.
Remove spray arms and soak them in warm water or vinegar.
Run an empty hot cycle with dishwasher cleaner to flush the interior.

problems.name: Cloudy or etched glass
problems.description: Glasses look dull, cloudy, or etched after repeated washes.

causes.name: High temperature with soft water leading to etching

actions.title: Lower the glassware wash temperature
actions.summary: Soft water and very hot cycles can etch delicate glass.
instructions: Select a program that keeps the main wash between 50°C and 55°C.
Use the Glass or Eco cycle for loads dominated by stemware.
Avoid sanitize or heavy-duty cycles when washing fine glass.

actions.title: Reduce rinse-aid dosing
actions.summary: Too much rinse aid can leave a milky film on glass.
instructions: Turn the rinse-aid setting down to level 1 or the lowest notch.
Disable rinse aid temporarily and test one cycle.
Reintroduce rinse aid gradually until spotting stops without clouding.

causes.name: Hard water film or calcium deposits

actions.title: Remove calcium build-up
actions.summary: Mineral deposits leave a cloudy sheen that mimics etching.
instructions: Run one cycle with dishwasher cleaner or citric acid to descale the interior.
Verify the salt system is filled and adjusted to local hardness.
Hand-wash cloudy glass with warm vinegar, then test again in a gentle cycle.

actions.title: Handle delicate glassware carefully
actions.summary: Some crystal or decorated glass is prone to permanent damage.
instructions: Confirm the manufacturer labels the glassware as dishwasher safe.
Place fragile pieces on the top rack away from heating elements.
If clouding persists, hand-wash the affected pieces to avoid etching.

problems.name: Greasy film on dishes
problems.description: A greasy sheen or residue covers plates and pans after washing.

actions.title: Increase wash heat
actions.summary: Grease needs sustained heat to liquefy and rinse away.
instructions: Choose an Intensive or Heavy cycle that reaches at least 65°C.
Confirm the hot-water supply entering the dishwasher is hot from the tap.
Use hot start or preheat the water by running the sink for 30 seconds.

causes.name: Cycle too short for grease breakdown

actions.title: Run a full-length heavy soil cycle
actions.summary: Short programs may skip crucial soaking and hot rinses.
instructions: Select Heavy or Intensive with a hot rinse option enabled.
Avoid Rapid or Express cycles when washing greasy pans.
Add an extra rinse or drying booster if available.

actions.title: Boost detergent dosing
actions.summary: More detergent helps break down oils and hold them in suspension.
instructions: Increase detergent or device output one step for the next wash.
Use a degrease or boost mode if your machine offers it.
After results improve, dial back to the minimum amount that keeps dishes clean.

causes.name: Grease buildup in filters or arms

actions.title: Degrease internal parts
actions.summary: Residual grease on filters and spray arms re-deposits on dishes.
instructions: Clean the filter thoroughly using hot water and mild detergent.
Soak spray arms or run them under hot water with vinegar to dissolve grease.
Run an empty hot cycle with dishwasher cleaner to flush the hoses.

problems.name: Streaks or lines on dishes
problems.description: Waxy streaks appear on plates or glass surfaces after drying.

actions.title: Dial back rinse-aid dosing
actions.summary: Excess rinse aid can leave streaks as it dries.
instructions: Lower the rinse-aid setting to level 1 or the minimum.
If streaks continue, temporarily disable rinse aid for one load.
Wipe the dispenser nozzle to prevent drips onto dishes.

actions.title: Re-balance the softener
actions.summary: Over-softened water leaves a slick residue.
instructions: Increase the water-hardness value on the built-in softener by one level.
If the unit uses salt, reduce regeneration frequency slightly.
Test with a hardness strip and adjust until streaks disappear.

actions.title: Cut back detergent volume
actions.summary: Too much detergent foams and drags residue across plates.
instructions: Reduce detergent by one tablespoon or one dispenser notch.
Use tablets or pods only when the load is full and heavily soiled.
If using pods, avoid pre-rinsing dishes to let enzymes work properly.

causes.name: Fast drying or door opened too early

actions.title: Slow the drying phase
actions.summary: Letting dishes cool gradually prevents streak formation.
instructions: Keep the door closed for at least 15 minutes after the cycle ends.
Use an extended dry or AutoOpen feature instead of propping the door immediately.
If your unit auto-opens, wait for the fan to finish before unloading.

problems.name: White film or chalky deposits
problems.description: A white film coats dishes and the dishwasher interior.

causes.name: High calcium or limescale in water

actions.title: Restore water softening
actions.summary: Calcium deposits accumulate when the softener cannot regenerate.
instructions: Fill the salt compartment and wipe away spills immediately.
Set the water-hardness level to match local ppm readings.
Run a limescale-clean mode or hot vinegar cycle to dissolve existing film.

actions.title: Service the softener system
actions.summary: If salt is present but film returns quickly, the softener needs attention.
instructions: Verify the salt cap seals and the float moves freely.
Break up any salt bridge and refill with fresh dishwasher salt.
If regeneration alarms appear, schedule technician support.

actions.title: Raise rinse-aid dosage
actions.summary: Rinse aid prevents calcium-laden water from drying on dishes.
instructions: Increase the rinse-aid dial to level 3.
If spotting persists, go up one notch until film disappears.
Use rinse-aid refills formulated for hard water when available.

actions.title: Alternate with full hot cycles
actions.summary: Short cycles never reach the temperatures needed to dissolve minerals.
instructions: Run a hot clean cycle with dishwasher cleaner once per week.
Avoid using only quick cycles; rotate in Normal or Intensive programs.
If film persists, run an empty sanitize or 65°C cycle with citric acid.

problems.name: Unpleasant odour
problems.description: A sour or musty smell comes from the dishwasher between uses.

causes.name: Trapped food in filter or seals

actions.title: Deep clean filters and door seals
actions.summary: Trapped food particles decompose and create odours.
instructions: Remove the filter assembly and scrub it with hot soapy water.
Wipe the door seal and folds with a vinegar-damp cloth.
Check the sump area for trapped food and remove any debris.

causes.name: Bacterial growth due to infrequent use

actions.title: Run maintenance cycles
actions.summary: Regular hot cycles keep bacteria from multiplying.
instructions: Run an empty hot rinse or sanitize cycle once a week when the dishwasher is idle.
Use an odor-removal or machine-cleaning mode if available.
Leave the door ajar slightly after cycles so the tub can dry.

actions.title: Drain and flush the system
actions.summary: Standing water becomes stale and smells over time.
instructions: Inspect and clean the drain area, removing any sludge.
Run a high-temperature sanitize cycle with a dishwasher cleaner.
Dry the filter and interior before reassembling if the machine will sit unused.

actions.title: Flush the drain path
actions.summary: Grease buildup traps odour-causing residue inside hoses.
instructions: Inspect the drain hose for kinks or buildup and straighten if needed.
Run an empty hot cycle with baking soda or dishwasher cleaner.
If odour remains, detach and rinse the hose or call for service.

problems.name: Discoloration or staining on dishes
problems.description: Dishes show yellowing, browning, or other color changes after washing.

causes.name: Excessive salt or improper softener regeneration

actions.title: Check and adjust salt system
actions.summary: Too much salt or improper regeneration can cause yellowing on ceramics.
instructions: Check if the salt reservoir is overfilled - drain excess if needed.
Verify the water hardness setting matches your local water supply.
Reduce the softener regeneration frequency by one level if available.
Run 2-3 empty hot cycles to flush excess salt from the system.

causes.name: Iron or minerals in water supply

actions.title: Address iron and mineral staining
actions.summary: Iron in water causes rust-colored or yellow stains on dishes.
instructions: Test your water supply for iron content - levels above 0.3 ppm cause staining.
Install a whole-house water filter or iron removal system if iron is high.
Run a cleaning cycle with citric acid or dishwasher cleaner to remove existing stains.
Consider using a rinse aid formulated for hard water with minerals.

actions.title: Remove tannin staining
actions.summary: Tea and coffee can leave brownish stains if not rinsed properly.
instructions: Pre-rinse cups and mugs that held tea or coffee before loading.
Use a hotter cycle (65°C) when washing tea-stained items.
Add a dishwasher cleaner tablet or oxygen bleach to the cycle.
For stubborn stains, soak items in warm water with baking soda before washing.

actions.title: Change detergent formulation
actions.summary: Some detergents react with certain materials causing discoloration.
instructions: Switch to a different detergent brand or formulation (powder vs. liquid vs. tablet).
Avoid chlorine-based detergents on colored or decorated ceramics.
Test with a gentler, fragrance-free detergent on the affected items.
Wash delicate or colored ceramics on the gentlest cycle available.

problems.name: Image analysis inconclusive
problems.description: Uploaded imagery does not clearly show the dishwasher situation.

actions.title: Improve lighting for images
actions.summary: Bright, even lighting lets the assistant inspect the racks.
instructions: Turn on room lights and avoid using flash directly on reflective surfaces.
Hold the phone steady with two hands to reduce blur.
Capture a second photo if the first still looks dark or washed out.

actions.title: Capture the full rack
actions.summary: Seeing both racks helps diagnose loading or blockage issues.
instructions: Frame the photo so the top and bottom racks are both visible.
Step back slightly and keep the door fully open.
If needed, take two photos showing upper and lower areas separately.

actions.title: Add context images
actions.summary: Close-ups and context shots help the assistant reason about the issue.
instructions: Take a close-up of the problem item such as a cloudy glass or dirty plate.
Show the detergent device placement or filter area if relevant.
Upload multiple images when possible to give different perspectives.
